articles.headline: No Place for Heated Opinions
articles.snippet: A Discovery Channel series about changes in polar regions does not mention causes, avoiding the fury that often accompanies mention of climate change.
articles.abstract: A Discovery Channel series about changes in polar regions does not mention causes, avoiding the fury that often accompanies mention of climate change.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Frozen Planet,” the seven-hour series that has attracted millions of viewers to the Discovery Channel in recent weeks, shows Earth in extremis. On this planet, the poles are violently cold, yet are also atypically vulnerable to the warming trends that are endangering polar bear populations and causing huge chunks of ice to break off Greenland and Antarctica.

articles.headline: Baseball Has Its Worshipers, and at N.Y.U., You Get Credit
articles.snippet: A New York University class, “Baseball as a Road to God,” aims far higher than clichés about stadiums being “green cathedrals.”
articles.abstract: A New York University class, “Baseball as a Road to God,” aims far higher than clichés about stadiums being “green cathedrals.”
articles.lead_paragraph: On the night before opening day, the end of a baseball fan’s version of Advent, John Sexton entered his classroom at New York University to speak of Joe DiMaggio. He came to speak, too, of Ernest Hemingway and Gay Talese, of Lord Krishna and a sacred tree in the Amazon, and what he called “this notion of touching the ineffable.”

articles.headline: Home-Sharing? Don’t Ignore Liability
articles.snippet: If you are temporarily renting your home to out-of-town guests, check on your liability with your insurer should someone get hurt.
articles.abstract: If you are temporarily renting your home to out-of-town guests, check on your liability with your insurer should someone get hurt.
articles.lead_paragraph: In the last month or so, I’ve written one column raising questions about how your insurance company might feel about you putting your car up for rent by the hour and another about the fallout for a customer of a company called RelayRides after someone who rented her car died behind the wheel and injured four others in the process.

articles.headline: Bank of America Accord in Lawsuit Is Challenged
articles.snippet: Lawyers have agreed to settle a lawsuit against the company’s directors over its purchase of Merrill Lynch for $20 million, even though damages could reach $5 billion, according to plaintiffs of a parallel suit in Delaware.
articles.abstract: Lawyers have agreed to settle a lawsuit against the company’s directors over its purchase of Merrill Lynch for $20 million, even though damages could reach $5 billion, according to plaintiffs of a parallel suit in Delaware.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lawyers leading a class-action lawsuit in federal court in Manhattan against the directors of Bank of America over its purchase of Merrill Lynch have agreed to settle the matter for $20 million even though damages in the case could reach $5 billion, according to plaintiffs in a parallel suit against the bank’s board in Delaware.

articles.headline: Obama Sees Steep Dropoff in Cash From Major Donors
articles.snippet: The traditional big sources of campaign funds are not delivering for President Obama’s campaign as they did four years ago, leaving the president to rely much more on grass-roots support.
articles.abstract: The traditional big sources of campaign funds are not delivering for President Obama’s campaign as they did four years ago, leaving the president to rely much more on grass-roots support.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Obama’s re-election campaign is straining to raise the huge sums it is counting on to run against Mitt Romney, with sharp dropoffs in donations from nearly every major industry forcing it to rely more than ever on small contributions and a relative handful of major donors.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Confessore and Derek Willis

articles.headline: With Venezuelan Food Shortages, Some Blame Price Controls
articles.snippet: Staples like milk, meat and toilet paper can be hard to find in Venezuela, and many blame the government’s price-control policies.
articles.abstract: Staples like milk, meat and toilet paper can be hard to find in Venezuela, and many blame the government’s price-control policies.
articles.lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — By 6:30 a.m., a full hour and a half before the store would open, about two dozen people were already in line. They waited patiently, not for the latest iPhone, but for something far more basic: groceries.

articles.headline: Concern in G.O.P. Over State Focus on Social Issues
articles.snippet: Some Republicans, eager to focus attention on fiscal issues, fear that a flurry of socially conservative legislation in states across the country could hurt the party in the fall.
articles.abstract: Some Republicans, eager to focus attention on fiscal issues, fear that a flurry of socially conservative legislation in states across the country could hurt the party in the fall.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fiscal issues and union rights were front and center in many Republican-controlled legislatures last year. But this year, with the nation heading into the heart of a presidential race and voters consumed by the country’s economic woes, much of the debate in statehouses has centered on social issues.

articles.headline: Wal-Mart Hushed Up a Vast Mexican Bribery Case
articles.snippet: Confronted with evidence of widespread corruption in Mexico, top Wal-Mart executives focused more on damage control than on rooting out wrongdoing, an examination by The New York Times found.
articles.abstract: Confronted with evidence of widespread corruption in Mexico, top Wal-Mart executives focused more on damage control than on rooting out wrongdoing, an examination by The New York Times found.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — In September 2005, a senior Wal-Mart lawyer received an alarming e-mail from a former executive at the company’s largest foreign subsidiary, Wal-Mart de Mexico. In the e-mail and follow-up conversations, the former executive described how Wal-Mart de Mexico had orchestrated a campaign of bribery to win market dominance. In its rush to build stores, he said, the company had paid bribes to obtain permits in virtually every corner of the country.

articles.headline: Employees, Too, Want a Say on the Boss’s Pay
articles.snippet: As more shareholders speak up about executive compensation, one group could become an especially formidable force: workers who own stock in their own companies.
articles.abstract: As more shareholders speak up about executive compensation, one group could become an especially formidable force: workers who own stock in their own companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: FINALLY, the shareholders are stirring.

articles.headline: When a Sugar High Isn’t Enough
articles.snippet: In a world with less time for cereal, the Kellogg team in Battle Creek, Mich., is leaping into new snack markets — as reflected in its pending deal for Pringles.
articles.abstract: In a world with less time for cereal, the Kellogg team in Battle Creek, Mich., is leaping into new snack markets — as reflected in its pending deal for Pringles.

articles.headline: In Customer Service Consulting, Disney’s Small World Is Growing
articles.snippet: Desperate for new ways to connect with consumers, an increasing array of industries and organizations are hiring the Disney Institute, the low-profile consulting division of the Walt Disney Company.
articles.abstract: Desperate for new ways to connect with consumers, an increasing array of industries and organizations are hiring the Disney Institute, the low-profile consulting division of the Walt Disney Company.
articles.lead_paragraph: ORLANDO, Fla. — Maryland teachers were instructed to engage children by crouching and speaking to them at eye level. Chevrolet dealers were taught to think in theater metaphors: onstage, where smiles greet potential buyers, and offstage, where sales representatives can take out-of-sight cigarette breaks.

articles.headline: Conservative Nonprofit Acts as a Stealth Business Lobbyist
articles.snippet: The American Legislative Exchange Council, whose members include lawmakers and corporations, drafts legislation on which 1,000 bills introduced annually in state legislatures are based.
articles.abstract: The American Legislative Exchange Council, whose members include lawmakers and corporations, drafts legislation on which 1,000 bills introduced annually in state legislatures are based.
articles.lead_paragraph: Desperate for new revenue, Ohio lawmakers introduced legislation last year that would make it easier to recover money from businesses that defraud the state.

articles.headline: ‘Presidential’ vs. ‘Political’ Trips: A Blurry Line, and Tricky Math
articles.snippet: Mixing policy and politics, President Obama is picking up the pace of his travel with that ultimate incumbent’s perk — unlimited use of Air Force One.
articles.abstract: Mixing policy and politics, President Obama is picking up the pace of his travel with that ultimate incumbent’s perk — unlimited use of Air Force One.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Facing 5,000 enthusiastic students at Florida Atlantic University, President Obama rolled up his sleeves and raised his voice to chastise Republicans for their spending cuts and “broken-down theories,” evoking chants of “Four more years!”

articles.headline: In Uprooting of Kurds, Iraq Tests a Fragile National Unity
articles.snippet: Facing attacks, Kurds are fleeing for Kurdish-majority areas amid a deteriorating relationship between Kurdish leaders and the Arab-dominated government in Baghdad.
articles.abstract: Facing attacks, Kurds are fleeing for Kurdish-majority areas amid a deteriorating relationship between Kurdish leaders and the Arab-dominated government in Baghdad.
articles.lead_paragraph: KHANAQIN, Iraq — In January, the dismembered body of Wisam Jumai, a Kurdish intelligence officer, was discovered in a field in Sadiyah, a small town in northeastern Iraq. Soon his family and friends, one after another, received text messages offering a choice: leave or be killed.

articles.headline: Hollande and Sarkozy Head to Runoff in French Race
articles.snippet: François Hollande, the Socialist challenger, came out on top in the first round of French presidential elections, but his lead over the incumbent, Nicolas Sarkozy, was slim.
articles.abstract: François Hollande, the Socialist challenger, came out on top in the first round of French presidential elections, but his lead over the incumbent, Nicolas Sarkozy, was slim.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Socialist candidate, François Hollande, won a narrow victory in Sunday’s first round of France’s presidential elections, riding promises of economic growth and a general dislike for the incumbent, Nicolas Sarkozy, into a favorable position before a runoff with Mr. Sarkozy on May 6.

articles.headline: With Pact, U.S. Agrees to Help Afghans for Years to Come
articles.snippet: The draft of an agreement finalized on Sunday pledges American support for Afghanistan for 10 years after the withdrawal of troops at the end of 2014.
articles.abstract: The draft of an agreement finalized on Sunday pledges American support for Afghanistan for 10 years after the withdrawal of troops at the end of 2014.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — After months of negotiations, the United States and Afghanistan completed drafts of a strategic partnership agreement on Sunday that pledges American support for Afghanistan for 10 years after the withdrawal of combat troops at the end of 2014.

articles.headline: Aiming for Clarity, Fed Still Falls Short in Some Eyes
articles.snippet: Despite efforts at increasing transparency, the Federal Reserve’s pronouncements remain a catalyst for debate and confusion among investors and experts.
articles.abstract: Despite efforts at increasing transparency, the Federal Reserve’s pronouncements remain a catalyst for debate and confusion among investors and experts.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Reserve chairman, Ben S. Bernanke, has tried to speak more clearly and more frequently than his predecessors. He has lectured college students, met with members of the military and, since last April, held quarterly news conferences.

articles.headline: TV Corrects Itself, Just Not on the Air
articles.snippet: Newspapers run corrections all the time, but a mistake on television news, like NBC’s misleading editing of an audio clip by George Zimmerman, is often followed by silence.
articles.abstract: Newspapers run corrections all the time, but a mistake on television news, like NBC’s misleading editing of an audio clip by George Zimmerman, is often followed by silence.
articles.lead_paragraph: After broadcasting an audio clip on the “Today” show about George Zimmerman last month that hit the trifecta of being misleading, incendiary and dead-bang wrong, NBC News management took serious action: it fired the producer in charge and issued a statement apologizing for making it appear as if Mr. Zimmerman had made overtly racist statements.

articles.headline: Agreement on a Global Firewall, but Little Beyond That
articles.snippet: The International Monetary Fund won significant pledges this weekend, but meetings ended without a consensus on how to speed up the economic recovery or stamp out the European debt crisis.
articles.abstract: The International Monetary Fund won significant pledges this weekend, but meetings ended without a consensus on how to speed up the economic recovery or stamp out the European debt crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Meetings of finance ministers and central bankers here over the weekend started with a pledge by wealthy nations to significantly increase the lending capacity of the International Monetary Fund to defend against the possibility of worsening economic conditions in the debt-laden euro zone.

articles.headline: Start-Up Aims to Stream Pay TV Onto Web Devices
articles.snippet: NimbleTV is the latest example of technology companies trying to break into the closed system of television distribution in the United States.
articles.abstract: NimbleTV is the latest example of technology companies trying to break into the closed system of television distribution in the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: In a move that could hasten the slow pace of so-called TV Everywhere, a technology start-up is introducing a way to move a whole subscription’s worth of TV onto the Web, with or without the subscription company’s permission.

articles.headline: Prime-Time Ratings Bring Speculation of a Shift in Habits
articles.snippet: Across the television landscape, viewing for all sorts of prime-time shows is down — chiefly among 18- to 49-year olds, the most important audience for the business.
articles.abstract: Across the television landscape, viewing for all sorts of prime-time shows is down — chiefly among 18- to 49-year olds, the most important audience for the business.
articles.lead_paragraph: It is the police procedural that has network executives scratching their heads this season: The Case of the Disappearing Viewers.

articles.headline: Justices to Rule on Role of the States in Immigration
articles.snippet: Many states are watching to see if the Supreme Court upholds Arizona’s tough law directed at those who cross the border illegally.
articles.abstract: Many states are watching to see if the Supreme Court upholds Arizona’s tough law directed at those who cross the border illegally.
articles.lead_paragraph: LENOX, Ga. — When Georgia passed a law last year authorizing the local police to question and detain illegal immigrants, Darvin Eason felt the impact immediately on his farms here in south Georgia.

articles.headline: Shift on Executive Power Lets Obama Bypass Rivals
articles.snippet: With Congressional Republicans blocking his agenda, the president has been using executive powers to enact measures: on the environment, education, drug shortages and making recess appointments.
articles.abstract: With Congressional Republicans blocking his agenda, the president has been using executive powers to enact measures: on the environment, education, drug shortages and making recess appointments.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One Saturday last fall, President Obama interrupted a White House strategy meeting to raise an issue not on the agenda. He declared, aides recalled, that the administration needed to more aggressively use executive power to govern in the face of Congressional obstructionism.

articles.headline: A Hit Maker Bets Future Earnings on an Expansion Plan
articles.snippet: The entertainment entrepreneur Peter Chernin has made an arrangement with investors, who are taking a stake in the future earnings of his films and television shows and channeling him the money now.
articles.abstract: The entertainment entrepreneur Peter Chernin has made an arrangement with investors, who are taking a stake in the future earnings of his films and television shows and channeling him the money now.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Insiders use outside money to make movies and television shows. That is the basic rule of Hollywood investment.
